In Syria, the return of exiles: 'I've been waiting for this moment for 14 years'
subhead: 'Syria after Assad' (2/4). Since the fall of Bashar al-Assad's dictatorial regime one year ago, more than 1.2 million exiled Syrians have returned home. The journey back has often been extremely difficult, but it is driven by a determination to rebuild their lives in their homeland.

title: Zelensky says ready to hold Ukraine elections
Trapped by old treaties with Russia, Europeans face the threat of heavy financial penalties
'American-style capitalism is inseparable from its philanthropic side'
subhead: Michael Dell, the founder of tech giant Dell Technologies, has just announced a $6.25 billion donation to American children, offering a pure lesson in philanthropic capitalism, summarizes columnist Nicolas Chapuis.

title: Luigi Mangione's to-do list revealed in court: 'Pluck eyebrows ... keep momentum, FBI slower overnight'
subhead: The notes found during the 27-year-old's arrest at a Pennsylvania McDonald's, shown on Monday at a pretrial hearing in NYC, included a hand-drawn map and survival tactics. Mangione has pleaded not guilty to state and federal murder charges for the killing of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson last December.

title: In Japan, disinformation is spreading as right-wing influence grows
subhead: Japan's ongoing political and social crises have fueled a climate of anxiety and a surge in right-wing radicalization, particularly among young people. The right has taken advantage of this to whitewash the facts of the war (1931-1945).

title: President Nicusor Dan: 'In Romania, we do not have a real policy to defend against disinformation'
subhead: Romania borders Ukraine and is at the front line against Russian interference, which led to the cancellation of the presidential election a year ago. In an interview with Le Monde, President Nicusor Dan, elected in May, revisits the matter and discusses the differences between Europe and the US regarding the war in Ukraine.
byline: Interview by Jean-Baptiste Chastand (Bucharest (Romania) special correspondent) and Marine Leduc

The incomplete transformation of Syria's Ahmed al-Sharaa, Islamist rebel turned president
subhead: 'Syria after Assad' (1/4). The man who toppled Syria's Baathist regime has succeeded in breaking the country's international isolation. Yet the former jihadist, who governs with a handful of loyal followers, has struggled to defuse the sectarian and ethnic tensions left by the civil war.
byline: By Hélène Sallon (Damascus, Syria, special correspondent) and Madjid Zerrouky (Damascus, Syria, special correspondent)

title: France's far-right Rassemblement National wants to reopen brothels
subhead: MP Jean-Philippe Tanguy, who is preparing a bill to create cooperatives managed by sex workers themselves, says penalizing customers has worsened the situation of sex workers.
byline: By Denis Cosnard and Clément Guillou

title: When Christmas presents are secondhand: 'My sisters looked at me strangely'
subhead: Far from consumerist extravaganzas like 'Black Friday' or 'Cyber Monday,' some people in France prefer to turn to secondhand and recycled goods for their holiday shopping. Juggling the risks of technical failure and the fear of being seen as 'cheapskates,' they share their experiences.
